section.title: Upgrading OTRS from 5 to 6
section.para: These instructions are for people upgrading OTRS from 5 to 6 or from a 5 to a later patchlevel release 5 and applies both for RPM and source code (tarball) upgrades.

If you are running a lower version of OTRS you have to follow the upgrade path to 5 first (1.1->1.2->1.3->2.0->2.1->2.2->2.3->2.4->3.0->3.1->3.2->3.3->4->5)! You need to perform a full upgrade to every version in between, including database changes and the upgrading Perl script.
Please note that if you upgrade from OTRS 2.2 or earlier, you have to take an extra step.

Within a single minor version you can skip patch level releases if you want to upgrade. For instance you can upgrade directly from OTRS 6 patchlevel 2 to version 6 patchlevel 6. If you need to do such a "patch level upgrade", you should skip steps 6 and XXXXX.

warning.para: Please note that you need at least Perl 5.16 to run OTRS 6. If your system has an older Perl version, you need to update it first before updating OTRS.
For PostgreSQL based installations: please note that you need at least PostgreSQL 9.2 to run OTRS 6. If your system has an older PostgreSQL version, you need to update it first before updating OTRS.

section.para: It is highly recommended to perform a test update on a separate testing machine first.

section.title: Step 1: Stop all relevant services
section.para: Please make sure there are no more running services or cron jobs that try to access OTRS. This will depend on your service configuration, here is an example:

para.screen: shell> /etc/init.d/cron stop shell> /etc/init.d/postfix stop shell> /etc/init.d/apache stop

section.para: Stop OTRS cron jobs and the daemon (in this order):

para.screen: shell> cd /opt/otrs/ shell> bin/Cron.sh stop shell> bin/otrs.Daemon.pl stop

warning.para: Don't proceed without a complete backup of your system.

section.title: Step 3: Install the new release (tar or RPM)
Step 3.1: With the tarball:
section.screen: shell> cd /opt shell> mv otrs otrs-old shell> tar -xzf otrs-x.x.x.tar.gz shell> mv otrs-x.x.x otrs

section.title: Rejesha usanidi wa ma faili ya zamani
Rejesha data za makala
section.para: If you configured OTRS to store article data in the filesystem you have to restore the article folder to /opt/otrs/var/ or the folder specified in the SysConfig.

section.title: Restore already installed default statistics
section.para: If you have additional packages with default statistics you have to restore the stats xml files with the suffix *.installed to /opt/otrs/var/stats.

section.title: Set file permissions
section.para: Please execute the following command as root user to set the file and directory permissions for OTRS:
It will try to detect the correct user and group settings needed for your setup.

section.title: Step 3.2: With the RPM:
section.para: In this case the RPM update automatically restores the old configuration files and sets file permissions.

section.title: Step 4: Run the migration script
section.para: Please run the migration script (as the otrs user, NOT as root):
This script will perform many checks on your system and give you advice on how to install missing Perl modules etc., if that is required.

The migration script will ask you to set a time zone for OTRS. It is very important that you set the correct time zone (and keep it), otherwise date and time of data added after the upgrade (tickets, articles, etc.) will be stored with a different time zone than your existing data, leading to inconsistent data. The script will suggest possible time zones based on your previous configuration. In case you are not sure or made a mistake, you can change the OTRS time zone after the upgrade via SysConfig setting OTRSTimeZone.

warning.para: Do not continue the upgrading process if this script did not work properly for you. Otherwise data loss may occur.

section.title: Step 5: Restart your services
section.para: e. g. (depends on used services):

para.screen: shell> /etc/init.d/apache start shell> /etc/init.d/postfix start shell> /etc/init.d/cron start

section.para: Now you can log into your system.

section.title: Step 6: Check installed packages

note.para: The OTRS 5 packages are NOT compatible with OTRS 6, so you have to perform a package upgrade!

section.title: Step 7: Start the OTRS Daemon
section.para: The OTRS daemon is responsible for handling any asynchronous and recurring tasks in OTRS. The daemon also handles all GenericAgent jobs and must be started as the otrs user.

section.title: Step 8: Update and activate cron jobs
section.para: There are two default OTRS cron files in /opt/otrs/var/cron/*.dist, and their purpose is to make sure that the OTRS Daemon is running. They need to be activated by copying them without the ".dist" filename extension.

para.screen: shell> cd /opt/otrs/var/cron shell> for foo in *.dist; do cp $foo `basename $foo .dist`; done

section.para: To schedule these cron jobs on your system, you can use the script Cron.sh as the otrs user.

section.title: Step 9: Update system registration (optional)
section.para: If the system is already registered with OTRS Group, it is strongly recommended to update the registration information at this time. This will update the registered version of the system (among other changes) in the OTRS Group records, in order to get much accurate information from the cloud services.

If you don't update the registration information manually, it will be done automatically on a regular basis, but this could happen some hours or days after. During this period it might be possible to get wrong information from cloud services like OTRS Business Solutionâ„¢ updates.

para.screen: shell> cd /opt/otrs/ shell> bin/otrs.Console.pl Maint::Registration::UpdateSend --force shell> bin/otrs.Console.pl Maint::Cache::Delete
